systems.text: (VCU) are designed for pumping gases, vapors and vapor-liquid mixtures in order to create a vacuum in different devices and vessels (various columns, desorbers, evaporators, deaerators, reactors and others).
(JC) are designed for compression low pressure gases generated in technological processes at various enterprises (for example, refinery, petrochemical and during oil and gas production).
(JAU) are designed for purification outlet gases (abgases) from hydrocarbons and recovery of oil and petroleum product vapors at loading racks, terminals and tank parks.

operation.title: Operating principle (the example of a single-stage VCU)
blocks: The pumped-out media from technological device is supplied to the inlet of VHC device 1. Here the vapor-gas mixture is compressed due to the energy of working fluid jet supplied to device 1 by pump 4. One of the process streams of the unit can be used as a working fluid, which can be mixed with pumped vapors (for example, diesel fraction and gasoil are used in refinery).

The resulting liquid-gas mixture flows from VHC device 1 into separator 2, where gas and liquid are separated. Compressed to required pressure gas is supplied for further use or disposal. After cooling in heat exchanger 3, the working fluid is again supplied to the VHC device 1 by pump 4. If it is necessary to refresh the working fluid, it is replenished and the balance excess is removed from the system.

operation.title: Operating principle
blocks: The pumped-out media from technological device is supplied to the inlet of steam ejector 1. The movement and compression of the vapor-gas mixture occurs due to the energy of superheated steam jet supplied to the ejector 1 by stream II. After steam ejector 1 the resulting vapor-gas mixture enters the condenser 4, where cooling and condensation occurs.

In the same way compressed to the the required pressure vapor-gas mixture is supplied to the inlet of the next stage steam ejector. Number of stages is defined by the range of the required absolute pump-out pressure and compression pressure at the unit outlet.
Condensate from the entire VCU is sent to separator 7 for liquids separation and their further use or disposal.

operation.title: Operating principle of the unit based on liquid JC
blocks: The low pressure gas to be compressed is supplied to the inlet of JC 1. The gas compression occurs in it due to the energy of working fluid jet supplied to the device 1 by pump 4. One of the process streams of the unit can be used as a working fluid, which can be mixed with pumped media.

The resulting liquid-gas mixture flows from JC into separator 2, where gas and liquid are separated. Compressed to required pressure gas is supplied for further use or disposal. After cooling in heat exchanger 3, the working fluid is again supplied to the JC 1 by pump 4. If it is necessary to refresh the working fluid, it is replenished and the balance excess is removed from the system.

In the case of variable compressed gas flowrate, several JC and working fluid pumps are connected to one separator. Thus, the performance of the unit can be controlled by automatically turning on or off the pumps and JC. This approach allows you to effectively respond to changes in gas flowrate and eliminate the use of gas tanks.

operation.title: Operating principle of the vapor-gas JC
blocks: Vapor-gas JC belong to the class of gas ejectors, in the flow channel of which two jets are mixed, accompanied by an increase in the pressure of the low-pressure (passive) gas due to the energy of the high-pressure (active) gas flow.

Steam, mixtures of hydrocarbon gases and any other gaseous media can be used as working fluid. In this regard, JC of this type are widespread and used in the oil and gas, chemical, metallurgical, energy, paper, food and other industries.

It is systems for recovery of light hydrocarbon fractions that are considered the most promising, cause they can radically improve environmental friendliness and efficiency of all technological operations associated with the reception, storage and transportation of oil and petroleum products.

operation.title: Operating principle of the JAU for gasoline loading racks
blocks: The pumped-out vapor-air mixture I from the gasoline loading rack is supplied to the inlet of the jet device 1. Gasoline is used as the working fluid for the jet device, which is supplied by pump 4. As a result of the ejection process in the jet device, the vapor-air mixture is compressed and gasoline vapor is absorbed by working fluid.

After the jet device the gas-liquid mixture enters separator 2, where gasoline vapors are further absorbed by the working fluid and air is separated. The final purification of the air from the hydrocarbon vapors occurs in the absorber 5, into which gasoline cooled in the chilling unit 6 is supplied as an absorbent. The purified air after absorber 5 is discharged into the atmosphere.

Up to 99% of hydrocarbons are extracted from the vapor-gas stream entering the JAU. The pressure in absorber 5 is maintained using a regulator valve installed on the gas outlet of the JAU. The circulating working fluid from separator 2 is supplied for cooling to heat exchanger 3 (installed if necessary), after which it is supplied to pump 4. To renew the working fluid, replenishment with fresh gasoline III is provided. Excess working fluid IV through the level control valve in separator 2 is removed from the unit to the loading rack or to the tank park

operation.title: Operating principle of the JAU for oil vapor recovery
blocks: Unit is designed for the light hydrocarbon fractions recovery from outlet gases (abgases), generated during oil loading into railway tanks or tankers.

Abgases from the oil loading rack 1 through line I at the pressure P0 are supplied to the inlet of the jet device 2 and compressed to the pressure P1. Oil that is supplied by pump 13 is used as the working fluid for jet device 2. During the compression and mixing of abgases with oil, the process of vapor absorption by the working fluid occurs.

After jet device 2 resulting gas-liquid mixture enters the separator 5, where separation of partially purified abgases and oil occurs. Then oil from the separator enters the inlet of pump 8 and after that is again supplied to the jet device 2.

To maintain efficiency of the absorption process and to remove heat from the circulation circuit, a portion of fresh oil is supplied to the first compression stage via line II. That oil is pumped from tanks 14 into railway tanks 1 (or tankers). Excess oil is removed from separator 5 via line III.

The second compression stage operates similarly, that consists of the gas-liquid jet device 3, the separator 6 and the pump 9. In the second stage abgases pressure rises to the value P2, and at the same time the degree of abgases purification from oil vapor increases.

The final purification takes place in the third stage, in which the pressure rises to the value P3. In the liquid circuit of the third compression stage, the diesel fraction is used as the working fluid, which is supplied by pump 10 to the jet device 4. During compression and mixing of abgases with the diesel fraction, the remaining oil vapors in the gas are absorbed.

In order to maintain absorption capacity, the diesel fraction is regenerated in desorber 12. The diesel fraction saturated with oil vapors from separator 7 at the pressure P3 enters desorber 12, in which pressure is maintained close to the value of pressure P0 at inlet of jet device 2. The oil vapors released in this case enter inlet of jet device 2 and are absorbed in the first compression stages.

The heat generated in the third stage is removed using an air-cooled or shell-and-tube heat exchanger 11. In case of of using a shell-and-tube heat exchanger, oil supplied to the loading rack can be used as a coolant.

The values of the purification degree are defined by continuous measurements of abgases flow rates and hydrocarbon concentrations in them at the inlet and outlet of the JAU and are calculated as the ratio of the mass of hydrocarbons captured using the unit to the mass of hydrocarbons received at its inlet.
The JAU provides a high purification degree of abgases (more than 95%) from oil vapors with any content of sulfur compounds (hydrogen sulfide, methyl mercaptans and others).
